commander.name: Generale di Armata Mario Berti
commander.previous_service: Replaced Francesco Guidi as 10th Army commander in summer 1940
commander.notes: On sick leave during Operation Compass opening (9 Dec 1940). Replaced by Gariboldi, then Tellera on 23 Dec 1940.

supply_logistics.supply_status: Critical - Catastrophic logistics situation for 10th Army Q4 1940. Main supply base Tripoli 1800km from forward positions at Sidi Barrani. British Operation Compass (9 Dec 1940) exposed Italian supply vulnerabilities. Forward divisions at Sidi Barrani deployed in isolated fortified camps (Nibeiwa, Tummar, Maktila) with inadequate supply stocks. Fuel reserves critically low (3-5 days for motorized units), ammunition stocks depleted after September advance to Sidi Barrani (8-12 days combat load). Water supply adequate from coastal wells but delivery to forward camps problematic. Commander Berti on sick leave when Operation Compass launched - command confusion exacerbated supply crisis. By end of Q4 1940, 10th Army facing complete collapse.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Coastal plain (Cyrenaica) and rocky desert - mixed terrain favoring mechanized warfare

subordinate_units.notes: Italy's premier armored division. In Italy Q4 1940 preparing for Libya deployment (arrived Jan 1941). Some tank battalions already deployed separately to Libya.
Tripolitania garrison, NOT at Sidi Barrani front. Survived Operation Compass.

subordinate_units.unit_type: Divisione Autotrasportabile AS (Auto-transportable Infantry Division, North Africa Type)
subordinate_units.notes: AS-type division optimized for North Africa. Participated in Italian invasion of Egypt Sept 1940.
Coastal defense west of Tripoli. Reserve status during Operation Compass opening.
Gharyan garrison (south of Tripoli). NOT engaged in Operation Compass Dec 1940.

tactical_doctrine.role: Offensive field army tasked with conquest of Egypt and advance on Suez Canal. Reality: disastrous failure culminating in Operation Compass disaster (Dec 1940 - Feb 1941).
special_capabilities: Numerical superiority over British Western Desert Force (150,000 vs 36,000)
Air support from Regia Aeronautica (331 aircraft)
tactical_innovations: Fortified camp system at Sidi Barrani (FAILED - camps not mutually supporting)
known_issues: CRITICAL: Fortified camps at Sidi Barrani NOT mutually supporting - isolated strongpoints vulnerable to defeat in detail
CRITICAL: Logistics collapse - 1800km supply line from Tripoli, fuel/ammo critically low
CRITICAL: Commander Berti on sick leave when Operation Compass launched (9 Dec 1940) - command chaos
Inferior tank quality - L3/35 tankettes obsolete, M13/40 limited numbers
Weak anti-tank capability (47mm guns inadequate vs Matilda II)
Inadequate motor transport for sustained operations
Morale issues after static deployment at Sidi Barrani (Sept-Dec 1940)
Intelligence failure - British strength and intentions misjudged
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Mixed success. AS-type divisions had desert modifications. Water supply systems adequate. But overall logistical system collapsed under operational stress of 1800km supply line.

scenario_suitability: Italian invasion of Egypt (September 1940) - advance to Sidi Barrani
Operation Compass (9-11 December 1940) - British counter-offensive opening
Battle of Sidi Barrani (9-11 December 1940) - Italian defensive disaster
Pursuit to Bardia and Tobruk (December 1940 - January 1941)
Battle of Beda Fomm (February 1941) - final destruction of 10th Army
special_rules: Isolated Fortified Camps: Forward divisions at Sidi Barrani in non-mutually-supporting camps - vulnerable to defeat in detail
Supply Crisis: -2 to all combat rolls if fuel/ammo depleted (Dec 1940 onwards)
Command Chaos: Commander on sick leave 9 Dec 1940 - command confusion modifier
Numerical Superiority (Sept-Nov 1940): 150,000 Italians vs 36,000 British WDF
Equipment Inferiority: L3/35 tankettes ineffective vs British cruiser tanks and Matildas
Logistics Collapse: Operational tempo limited by fuel/ammo shortages
Morale Collapse: After Sidi Barrani disaster, morale rating drops to 3
historical_engagements: Italian invasion of Egypt (13 September 1940) - advanced 95km to Sidi Barrani
Operation Compass opening (9 December 1940) - catastrophic defeat
Battle of Sidi Barrani (9-11 December 1940) - 38,000 prisoners, Nibeiwa/Tummar camps destroyed
Battle of Beda Fomm (6-7 February 1941) - final destruction, 25,000 prisoners, General Tellera killed
Total losses Operation Compass: 133,298 prisoners, 420 tanks, 845 guns, complete destruction of 10th Army

source: Wikipedia: Operation Compass - 10th Army organization and Operation Compass casualties (Tier 2, 85% confidence)
Wikipedia: Mario Berti - Commander biography and sick leave during Operation Compass (Tier 2, 80% confidence)
Wikipedia: Italian Tenth Army - Organization and subordinate units (Tier 2, 82% confidence)
Web search: XXI Corps and XXII Corps organization at Sidi Barrani (Tier 2, 75% confidence)
Aggregated from 5 subordinate division files: Ariete, Pavia, Bologna, Brescia, Savona (Tier 1, 78-82% confidence per division)
TM E 30-420: Handbook on Italian Military Forces - Italian army organization (Tier 1, 85% confidence)
Cross-referenced: 10th Army had 150,000 personnel, 1,600 guns, 600 tanks/tankettes, 331 aircraft
Cross-referenced: Operation Compass losses 133,298 prisoners, 420 tanks, 845 guns
Cross-referenced: Commander Mario Berti replaced Guidi summer 1940, on sick leave 9 Dec 1940, replaced by Tellera 23 Dec 1940
validation.validated_by: Claude Code - Army-level aggregation from subordinate divisions
known_gaps: Chief of Staff name not documented in available sources
This army-level extraction aggregates ONLY 5 divisions (Ariete, Pavia, Bologna, Brescia, Savona) which were reserves/not at Sidi Barrani front
10th Army ACTUALLY had 9-10 divisions total in Q4 1940, including forward divisions (Cirene, Catanzaro, Sirte, Sabratha, Marmarica, etc.) NOT included here
Personnel totals (48,645) represent ONLY the 5 extracted divisions, NOT full 10th Army strength of ~150,000
Equipment totals similarly incomplete - only 5 divisions vs 10 total divisions
XXI Corps and XXII Corps had DIFFERENT divisions at Sidi Barrani front (Cirene, Catanzaro, Sirte, 23 Marzo, 28 Ottobre Blackshirt divisions)
Forward corps composition at Sidi Barrani NOT represented in this aggregation
Aircraft total 0 - Regia Aeronautica had ~331 aircraft supporting 10th Army but not organic to ground units
Libyan colonial divisions (1st, 2nd Libyan, Maletti Group) not included
This is a PARTIAL aggregation for demonstration - does NOT represent full 10th Army TO&E
validation.confidence_explanation: Confidence reduced to 72% (Tier 2 - review recommended) because this army-level aggregation represents ONLY 5 divisions extracted so far (Ariete, Pavia, Bologna, Brescia, Savona - primarily reserve divisions in Tripolitania), NOT the full 10th Army which had 9-10 divisions total in Q4 1940. Forward divisions at Sidi Barrani front (Cirene, Catanzaro, Sirte, Sabratha, Marmarica, plus Blackshirt divisions 23 Marzo, 28 Ottobre, 3 Gennaio, plus Libyan divisions and Maletti Group) are NOT included in this aggregation. Personnel total 48,645 represents only these 5 divisions vs actual 10th Army strength ~150,000. Equipment totals similarly incomplete. Commander Mario Berti confirmed (took command summer 1940, on sick leave 9 Dec 1940 when Operation Compass launched). Historical context of Operation Compass disaster well-documented (133,298 prisoners, 420 tanks lost, complete destruction). This file is intended as a PARTIAL demonstration of army-level aggregation methodology, acknowledging significant gaps for divisions not yet extracted. Supply/logistics data averaged from 5 subordinate divisions. Weather data for North African coastal region Q4 1940.
